facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1938 of 1966 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1938 of 1966.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated April 20, 1966 of Allahabad High Court in Second Appeal No. 2648 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 20, 1966 of the Allahabad High Court in Second Appeal No. 2648 of 1964.

facts.text: Respondent filed suit against appellant for eviction from a shop taken on monthly rent from respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent filed a suit against the appellant for eviction from a shop which the appellant had taken on monthly rent from the respondent.

facts.text: Suit filed after permission obtained under U.P. Temporary Control of Rent and Eviction Act, No. III of 1947 in court of Munsif in Jhansi.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was filed after permission had been obtained under the U.P.  Temporary Control of Rent and Eviction Act, No. III of 1947,  hereinafter referred to as the Act , in the companyrt of the Munsif in Jhansi.

facts.text: Appellant contested suit raising point that permission granted during stay order was nullity lacking jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: It was companytested by the appellant and one of the points raised before the trial companyrt was that as the permission to sue had been granted at a time when there was a stay order, the Magistrate granting the permission had numberjurisdiction to do so and therefore the permission was a nullity.

facts.text: Munsif dismissed the suit.

anchor.surface_text: The Munsif dismissed the suit.

facts.text: Respondent appealed and appeal court upheld Munsif's order viewing permission as nullity.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then went in appeal. The appeal companyrt upheld the order of the Munsif taking the view that the permission granted after the stay order had been passed was a nullity.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court in second appeal held permission valid as Magistrate had no knowledge of stay order passed on September 29, 1961, and granted decree for ejectment and rent.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then came in second appeal to the High Court, and the only point companysidered there was whether the permission granted by the Magistrate was a nullity or number. It may be mentioned that though the stay order had been passed on September 29, 1961 by the District Magistrate, the Magistrate who was dealing with the matter of permission, had numberknowledge of it when he granted the permission on October 4, 1961.

facts.text: Stay order passed on September 29, 1961 by District Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that though the stay order had been passed on September 29, 1961 by the District Magistrate,

facts.text: Magistrate granted permission on October 4, 1961 without knowledge of stay order.

anchor.surface_text: the Magistrate who was dealing with the matter of permission, had numberknowledge of it when he granted the permission on October 4, 1961.

facts.text: Facts on the question raised are not in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: As we have already indicated, the facts on the question raised before us are number in dispute.

facts.text: Application for permission pending before Sri Nigam, Magistrate I Class, delegated by District Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: When the application for permission was pending before Sri Nigam, Magistrate I Class, who had jurisdiction to deal with that application by virtue of the authority delegated to him by the District Magistrate,

facts.text: Appellant applied for transfer of permission proceedings from Sri Nigam.

anchor.surface_text: it appears that the appellant applied for the transfer of proceedings relating to permission from Sri Nigams companyrt.

facts.text: District Magistrate passed stay order on transfer application.

anchor.surface_text: On that transfer application, the District Magistrate passed an order staying further proceedings till the disposal of the transfer application.

facts.text: Stay order not communicated to Magistrate by District Magistrate's office.

anchor.surface_text: This order was number companymunicated to the Magistrate companycerned by the office of the District Magistrate.

facts.text: Appellant did not inform Magistrate of stay order.

anchor.surface_text: Nor does it appear that the appellant informed the Magistrate of the order of stay with the, result that on October 4, 1961,

facts.text: Magistrate gave permission to respondent on October 4, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: the Magistrate gave permission to the respondent to file a suit for eviction.

facts.text: In suit, appellant raised that permission was nullity due to stay order of September 29, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: When however the respondent filed the suit in the Munsifs Court, the appellant raised the question that as a stay order had been passed on September 29, 1961, the permission granted on October 4, 1961, was a nullity

facts.text: District Magistrate dismissed the transfer petition.

anchor.surface_text: Later on the District Magistrate himself dismissed the transfer petition.

facts.text: Stay order never brought to knowledge of Magistrate by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The order was number brought to the knowledge of the Magistrate companycerned by the appellant at any time.

facts.text: Appellant never applied to Magistrate to set aside permission.

anchor.surface_text: Nor did he ever apply to the Magistrate to set aside the permission passed in ignorance in the interest of justice.

facts.text: Appellant cannot challenge permission as nullity in suit.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances, the appellant cannot challenge the permission as a nullity in the suit which has been brought on the basis of that permission.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Wanchoo, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Wanchoo, j

facts.text: Yogeshwar Prasad and S. S. Khanduja for appellant; Hardev Singh for respondent.

anchor.surface_text: Yogeshwar Prasad and S. S. Khanduja, for the appellant. Hardev Singh, for the respondent.

facts.text: There is conflict of opinion between High Courts on effect of stay order.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, then obtained special leave from this Court, as there is some companyflict of opinion between the High Courts on this question.

issues.text: as the permission to sue had been granted at a time when there was a stay order, the Magistrate granting the permission had no jurisdiction to do so and therefore the permission was a nullity

anchor.surface_text: It was contested by the appellant and one of the points raised before the trial court was that as the permission to sue had been granted at a time when there was a stay order, the Magistrate granting the permission had no jurisdiction to do so and therefore the permission was a nullity. On that basis it was contended that the suit should fail for no suit could continue under the Act without such permission.

issues.text: whether the permission granted by the Magistrate was a nullity or not

anchor.surface_text: the only point considered there was whether the permission granted by the Magistrate was a nullity or not. It may be mentioned that though the stay order had been passed on September 29, 1961 by the District Magistrate, the Magistrate who was dealing with the matter of permission, had no knowledge of it when he granted the permission on October 4, 1961.

issues.text: whether the permission granted in these circumstances could be said to be a nullity

anchor.surface_text: The question that arose before the High Court therefore was whether the permission granted in these circumstances could be said to be a nullity. The High Court held that the stay order could not and did not take away the jurisdiction of the Magistrate from the moment it was passed and that as the Magistrate had no knowledge of or information about the stay order when he granted the permission on October 4, 1961,

issues.text: the question of the effect of a stay order, particularly with reference to execution proceedings

anchor.surface_text: There has been difference of opinion among the High Courts on the question of the effect of a stay order, particularly with reference to execution proceedings. The High Courts of Calcutta, Patna and Punjab have held that in such a case the stay order takes effect from the moment it is passed and the fact that the court executing the decree has no knowledge of it makes no difference and all proceedings taken in execution after the stay order has been passed are without jurisdiction.

issues.text: s. 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure would always be available to the court executing the decree, for in such a case, when the stay order is brought to its notice it can always act under S. 151, and set aside steps taken between the time the stay order was passed and the time it was brought to its notice

anchor.surface_text: Though the court which is carrying on execution is not deprived of the jurisdiction the moment a stay order is passed, even though it has no knowledge of it, this does not mean that when the court gets knowledge of it is powerless to undo any possible injustice that might have been caused to the party in whose favour the stay order was passed during the period till the court has knowledge of the stay order. We are of opinion that s. 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure would always be available to the court executing the decree, for in such a case,

issues.text: What we have said about execution proceedings applies with greater force to stay orders passed in transfer applications, as in the present case

arguments.claim: Executing court does not lose jurisdiction until knowledge of stay order; proceedings in between not nullity

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, the High Courts of Madras and Kerala have taken the view that the executing court does not lose its jurisdiction from the moment the stay order is passed and that the order being in the nature of a prohibitory order the court carrying on execution does not lose its jurisdiction to do so till the order comes to its knowledge and that proceedings taken in between are not a nullity.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: of execution, but it would only have that effect when it reached the companyrt or person whose duty

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court follows this view as correct

arguments.claim: View in Bessesswari Chowdhurany case is correct: stay order prohibitory, effective on communication

anchor.surface_text: In that case a Division Bench of the Calcutta High Court held that an order staying execution of a decree against which an appeal is pending is in the nature of a prohibitory order, and as such would only take effect when communicated.

arguments.claim: Stay order is prohibitory addressed to court, does not oust jurisdiction until known; court must obey only after knowledge

anchor.surface_text: An order of stay in an execution matter is in our opinion in the nature of a prohibitory order and is addressed to the court that is carrying out execution. It is not of the same nature as an order allowing an appeal and quashing execution proceedings.

arguments.claim: Stay order akin to injunction but addressed to court; knowledge required before prohibition effective; post-knowledge proceedings nullity

anchor.surface_text: In effect therefore a stay order is more or less in the same position as an order of injunction with one difference. An order of injunction is generally issued to a party and it is forbidden from doing certain acts.

arguments.claim: Mere filing appeal no stay; appellate stay effective only on communication to executing court per O. XLI R. 5 CPC

anchor.surface_text: This to our mind clearly follows from the words of O. XLI R. 5 of the Code of Civil Procedure which clearly lays down that mere filing of an appeal does not operate as stay of proceedings in execution, but the appellate court has the power stay of execution.

arguments.claim: Court can invoke S.151 CPC to set aside pre-knowledge proceedings if necessary for justice and application within reasonable time

No uncertainty from requiring knowledge as it can be proved by communication, affidavit etc.

anchor.surface_text: There is in our opinion no question of uncertainty, even if we hold that the stay order must come to the knowledge of the court to which it is addressed before it takes effect. The court may receive knowledge either on receipt of an order of stay from the court that passed it or through one party or the other supported by an affidavit
